comments.text:
The speaker's website says that she writes "books for kids," and she's 
releasing seven books in 2015, so it is what it is. That said, I don't 
think there's much more that's interesting to say about "world building" in 
general (although perhaps plenty of specifically interesting examples to 
explore and analyze). The whole world building idea is kind of propped up 
way too high among writers these days anyway, probably due to the 
popularity of *Harry Potter*, *The Lord of the Rings*, *The Hunger Games*, *A 
Song of Fire and Ice*, *Twilight*, *Percy Jackson & the Olympians*, *The 
Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy*, etc. It's definitely a trend. Not saying 
it's bad, or that "worlds" are negligible, but that this TED-Ed definitely 
reflects the current book market and its ethos more so than any 
trans-generational template for all kinds of writers.

top_comment.text:
If you want a lesson in world building become a Game Master for a game like 
D&D. Some people use modulars, but for me nothing beats the feel of a well 
hand crafted world.
Not only does it help create the world, but it also fleshes it out. As 
players start to explore, question, and even break aspects of your world it 
forces you to think of aspects that you may not have even bothered with. 
It makes the world feel as though it is living, and that you and your 
players have an actual stake in it.

Hell one of my favorite shows is Adventure Time. The Land of Ooo feels like 
this living breathing world that you could live in, because it is so well 
detailed. A lot of the writers have remarked that sometimes when they are 
writing an episode they play it out like a pen and paper RPG. Not only to 
get a good idea of how the characters would react, but what part of the 
world they are reacting too.﻿
top_comment.author: Chandler Hull

comments.text:
+John Smith Late, but here's a Glossary:

WoD: World of Darkness, a tabletop roleplaying game.
ST: Storytelling
GM: Game Master, the person in charge of directing the game, describing the 
world, etc., to the players.
DM: Dungeon Master, same as GM, but is vernacular specific to Dungeons and 
Dragons, you may also come across Quest Master (QM) in some game systems.

That should help you. From there you'll have to explore tabletop games 
yourself, as each group, system, and GM will interact differently. My 
recommendation is to find someone who is experienced with tabletop gaming 
and sit in on a game.

I was actually thinking about that when she said "literally build worlds." 
Depending on how you're considering it, that could be correct usage of the 
word "literally." Since fictional worlds aren't built out of physical 
matter, you could say that fictional worlds are composed out of ideas - you 
could say they're made of thoughts rather than atoms. So to build a 
fictional world, instead of organizing physical matter into different 
forms, a writer would have to organize ideas into different forms. That 
would mean that by coming up with and writing down ideas, a writer is 
literally building a fictional world. It's not a real world, but it's a 
real fictional world.

“PIPPIN: I didn't think it would end this way.

comments.text:
Honestly you can take inspiration from anything! Movies, tv shows, books, 
video games, anything that sparks your interest can help you have an idea 
of what is interesting or worthwhile. A novel I am currently writing came 
from multiple inspirations. I studied how they expressed their stories in 
order to translate to mine. Lord of the Rings, Narnia, A Game of Thrones, 
Redwall, Avatar last air bender, Skyrim, Star Wars, Pokemon, and most 
importantly History all gave me inspiration on different types of conflict, 
character development, and structure. Last bit of advice is, if you can, to 
have someone who is also writing to help you edit, brainstorm, or give 
feedback. Tolkien and C. S. Lewis were long time friends and were in a 
writing group together. Helping someone write no only makes them better but 
yourself as well.
comments.author: KnightScottish

comments.text: +Roger Engle Thank you. Wonderful advice.
comments.author: Tahja Tomlinson

comments.text:
Conflict and resolution can be taken from your own experience, the news, 
watching nature, whatever.  The thing you said about your fictional worlds 
sounding boring caught my attention because I have struggled with this 
myself, (not for writing novels, but for Dungeon Mastering back in the old 
days when role playing was done with dice and pencils and paper and long 
weekends with nerds sitting around a table in someone's basement.).  I 
recommend you take notes on what you observe about the writings of authors 
whom you think do a good job of making their fictional world seem real to 
you.  For instance, what did J.R.R. Tolkien do to make Middle Earth seem 
interesting?  I have noticed that he wrote pages and pages of descriptive, 
almost whimsical fancy about seemingly unimportant things, such as his 
description of the unassuming ways, habits and history of Hobbits.  That's 
a good observation.  He treated it as though it were real, at least for the 
purposes of writing about it.  He gave it feeling, beauty and history and 
then he mused about those things.  Each author handles problems like this 
one differently, but I'm sure you get my drift.  Endless observation of 
genius goes a long way toward displaying some for yourself.
Anyway, you sound as though you really want to succeed.  If you put in the 
long hours and the hard work, maybe you will.  Good luck!

comments.text:
Wow. Amazing the turns conversations take. Definition of "literally" to 
South Park to Christianity to morality and round and round. Phew... Anyway, 
It seems there's a lot of misconceptions on this chain (correct me if I 
have my own.)
First, I wish dictionary writers would stop accommodating incorrect usage 
of words by changing their meanings. it confuses things even more than 
before. Second, existence can be true for material things as well as ideas. 
I think the ability to be concious of something is the definition for its 
existence. If we are conscious of it, but it is immaterial (ignoring, for 
the moment, any materialist ideas (see what I did there? 
(Parenthesesception! (sorry))) of ideas being only electrical impulses) 
then, it is an idea. But that is still a literal existence. Literally can 
be used as a emphatic for a real (unexaggerated) event. Thus, the idea 
literally exists! And was literally created. A fictional world is a complex 
system that exists (literally) in the world of ideas. What you got confused 
on (I think) is that the word "build" can already mean both a material or 
mental construction. (Just like "fight" has physical and mental 
definitions.) But yes, the word "literally" was kind of awkwardly thrown in 
(It's not literally wrong though (see what I did again))(incidentally, the 
world "rhetorically" doesn't work too well either. (It can, but not well) 
The word I think you're looking for is "imaginatively", "literarily" (if 
that's a word), or otherwise "Writers build literary worlds.")
Third, for you Christians, you're drawing too much attention to atheist 
hostility, which wasn't hostility as you seem to be defining. Sure, 
atheists oppose the Christian worldview, which means they're hostile. But 
that doesn't mean they're being aggressive. Also, if you really want to 
spread the Word, don't focus on their hostility and continue to observe 
that, but try to address their problems with Christianity. Or, if you're 
dealing with particularly sarcastic ones, say you'll ignore them and then 
do it. Otherwise you go in circles as with now.
Finally, for you atheists. I haven't got time for a full treatise on 
religion, but I'd like to answer one of your ideas, that heaven is made up 
because it's a scapegoat for a fear of dying. However, just because heaven 
is a way out of death doesn't make it untrue. There's a difference between 
an excuse and a justification. Both are scapegoats, but the latter is a 
true one. The question is not whether something whether something is a 
convenient idea (the word again!), but whether something is true. (Your 
argument however, does seem to apply to Christians who think Hell doesn't 
exist)
Whew, sorry if I got too scholarly up there. Plus, sorry if I sound 
hateful. I'm just trying to clear people up when they're misled, and I'm 
just as happy when someone points out my faults. (Unless they're acting 
like a dick when they do it)
On a marginally related note, that was a nice video with amusing animation, 
but a little too vague for my tastes. I'd have preferred if you'd been more 
definite with at least one aspect of worldbuilding instead of the 
education-by-examples you gave.

tl;dr go back and read my argument dude. It's too complex for a couple of 
sentences. Oh, and I liked the video but thought it rather unspecific.

+Jack Robin Now Jack, imagine for a moment that I was to tell you that you

reasonable, sensible thing to say?  That's exactly what you're doing when

perspective.  Some of us, as I've already said, filter their perspective 
through religion.  Others do so through their faith or beliefs.  Still

 Whatever our perspective, we still have the same rights to join into a 
public discussion on YouTube.  If someone brought up religion, as you put

like that, though.  One minute you're talking about cars and the next thing

internet discussion.  The best that person can do is, if they have some

not, they can leave the discussion or refuse to continue taking part in it. 
 If you aren't happy with what other people have said in this discussion,

comments.text:
+Corey Messick Again not "ripped off", more "inspired by". Tolkien was a 
professor of Philology and had studied The Eddas (the collection of stories 
that make up Norse mythology) long before he began his work on anything 
related to Middle- earth(btw the world of humans in the Eddas is called 
Midgard, literally translated as "Middle-earth). The Eddas filled his head 
with ideas and inspiration, obviously he's going to use some of that 
inspiration in his works. If you look at for example the Lion King 
side-by-side to Hamlet you'll notice that they're basically the same story. 
Disney took inspiration from Shakespeare and made it into something new, 
something that was their own.

There is a line though. I don't think it's okay to just blatantly ripp 
something page by page out of something. For example Flappy Bird using old 
Mario assets in it's level design or (as much as i hate the movie) 
Sundayschool musical ripping of Highschool musical. That is just wrong.
comments.author: LordZeebee

comments.text: Gandalf was obviously ripped off!
comments.author: Corey Messick

comments.text:
+Amun-Ra I wouldn't call it stolen but very little fiction is completely 
unique and new. Tolkien for example has barely anything new in his works, 
most of it is inspired by old Norse mythology. Gandalf has the name of one 
of the first dwarves born from Ymir the giant's rotting flesh, his name 
means "Elf friend" in old norse and both his character and design is pretty 
much identical to Odin the Allfather's during his time as a disguised 
wanderer. Wide-brimmed hat, long flowing beard, wooden staff, grey robes 
and everything.

Notice what word i used though, "inspired". It wasn't borrowed or stolen it 
was inspired by Norse mythology. This is simply how culture works, we take 
in stories and expressions that other people have created from a life of 
experiences and use them to help shape who we are. We then proceed to 
create stories and expressions using our own experiences in life and what 
made us who we are today. Our works get consumed by younger people who then 
proceed to create their own stories and expressions from their experiences.

And so it keeps going and going and going...
comments.author: LordZeebee

comments.text:
The problem is it's easy to see a correlation between two stories if you 
find enough of them. Sure there's similarities between a bunch of stories, 
but that doesn't mean that the ideas were 'stolen'. Is every story with a 
wizard ripping off Tolkien? Is every story about a married couple ripping 
off the Honeymooners? Is every comedy cartoon ripping off the Simpsons?

comments.text:
+Zonne I generally have trouble starting writing, but I'm like a train: if 
I'm on a good track I can keep going, but I need to get past that tough 
start first.

Although, starting things just might be hard because it's hard for me to 
start a conversation, and I write and speak the same way.

Also-going back to that train-the story should generally flow. If it's hit 
a roadblock, you may have taken a wrong turn, or you just don't realize 
that you're on the right path, it's just not in plain sight, in which case, 
the experiencer won't see that path as flat out obvious either. So it may 
take a little bit, but it's generally useful.

And going back in time to Socrates, who taught by asking his students 
questions, look at the world we live in and when you see something, wonder 
"what if" in a general state about that thing. Maybe asking "what if that 
didn't exist?" or "what if that always happened?" or "what if that was the 
other way around?" Misinterpret as much as you can, as that will develop 
ideas and improve your understanding of language and your use of it in a 
way that isn't broad or confusing (unfortunately this also has the side 
effect of making other people really confusing, because they use language 
very broadly).
comments.author: Zachery Louis

comments.text:
+Zonne You don't have to wright to tell a story. You said that you like to 
draw, that's perfect! You can make a story just as complex and vibrant 
trough pictures as you can with words. All the different types of media can 
convey a narrative just as well as the written word, all of them have 
different benefits and drawbacks.

Books let you know the world from someone else's eyes, art lets you see and 
analyse a single moment in time in the world and all the emotions packed in 
that moment, film let's you see the world and the emotions of the 
characters from an outside perspective, music lets you hear the sounds and 
feel of the world and games let you experience the world for yourself 
either sharing the body of one if it's characters or on your own. All are 
valid forms of storytelling and provide different kinds of experiences.

If you ask me you should utilize every possible media if you want your 
world to really grow, both in width and in depth. I for example have been 
drawing bios for all the different races, creatures and places in my world 
for almost half a year now, i've created a virtual map of the world using a 
world editor for Minecraft, i've written a short story about my so far only 
fleshed out character and i'm planing on using my world as a basis for a 3d 
game i'm going to create as part of my final school project(i'm 18). Once 
the world and history is done i'm planing on writing some more short 
stories and moving on to draw more environmental drawings about the 
inhabitants of my world and how they interact with each other. Who knows, i 
might make a game or 2 as well if i have the time :)

comments.text:
+Zetseriel I'm not the best writer myself, but I know for one; the 
beginning is always the hardest.
So never start with the beginning.
Start with the Climax.
Start by thinking of all the characters that will be in your story, and 
then simply build around that.
Eventually you will make your way to the beginning.

And that story you just read that I wrote, I made it up while writing it.
So that's another good technique.
Write the story out multiple times, making it up as you go along but always 
keep the ending and beginning the same.
Then simply just put it together like a puzzle or maze, taking which path 
is the less cliche and the most exciting.

Also, when editing, USE AS MANY DESCRIPTIVE WORDS AS POSSIBLE!
Basically, explore your entire vocabulary for pretty much every sentence.

comments.text:
Ima write a book about you.
Here's how it will go...

Once upon a time there was a boy born with a curse; he was cursed to 
forever be a wet blanket.
As he grew and wondered through life aimlessly, he couldn't keep a friend 
because of his curse.
After doing his morning errands, and making a few people lose all hope in 
life; he comes home to find that his parents and his sister were brutally 
murdered in a break in gone wrong. (or was it?)
He stayed in his bed trying to sleep away the pain, drowning it in sugar 
free soda and action thrillers on netflix.
Until he came upon one action thriller that would change his life forever.
By watching this low rating film, he found his calling; to use his curse to 
fight crime!
The costume choice was obvious, a half blanket half cape, that was 
completely soaked.
His first victory was a mysterious figure lurking through the street lights 
who had an eye for this jewelry store with terrible security.
Suddenly glass shatters and the dark figure enters the building with a 
greedy heart and sticky fingers.
When the job was almost done and the criminal was on his way out, a strange 
figure appears preventing him from moving forward.
It was the Depressed Crusader!
Instantly the Depressed Crusader begins whipping the jewel thief with his 
fully saturated blanket.
After the jewel thief was on the ground in severe pain, the Joykill supreme 
begins to unleash his ultimate attack, his crime fighting duo, Sticks and 
Stones!
"You worthless scum! Your own mother wouldn't be proud of you! Look at you, 
you're stealing Jewels like some halfassed thief wannabe. If you weren't 
already so petty I would almost have pity for you!" the Depressed Crusader 
said.
With the thief in both physical and emotional pain, his capture was swift 
and effortless.

And once again, the day is saved by the power pu... Depressed Crusader!

How will this hero be molded into something more?
Or will his curse cease his reign of courage once and for all?
All great questions that will never be answered because the Depressed 
Crusader ruined my dream to continue being a writer!


Thumbs up me up if you want the story to turn into a Fandom!

+darklightlazer I know it's a long time coming, but a good resource would 
be this: http://www.arcadia.net/Cruinne/DnD/Articles/worldbuilding.html

It's more focused around worldbuilding for RPGs, but it should give you a 
better idea of the kind of considerations you'd have to make depending on 
your main character, side characters, motivations, etc. You'll have to 
think up the rough core of the land and characters you're working on first,

less likely to end up with continuity errors. Be creative, but don't forget 
that you can get inspiration from almost anywhere. Once you have the very 
basic core you should look up pictures of something similar and take visual 
cues and nuances from it.

top_comment.text:
You forgot the most important part!

You need a purpose--a reason--to your story.  An overall drive, a goal.  It 
needs to all mean something and everything needs to point that direction. 
 It only leads to a more coheasive, concise and entertaining and possibly 
enlightening experience for *all* involved.  Your laws and rules need a 
reason to be.  Your government (or lack thereof) has to serve its purpose 
in this world.  This is not as easy as it seems, but it is way more 
fulfilling than it seems as well.  Your world is important, but its still 
only a piece of the puzzle.﻿

comments.text:
+jocelyn montpetit  Well it's a different approach to storytelling, from 
the outside in. I.e. create a world, then think of a story worth telling 
within that world. It's much, much easier to start out with a good story, 
then create the world around it (in my opinion). If only because a universe 
has an infinite amount of possible stories to highlight, very easy to get 
sidetracked that way.

Story = conflict, the more intense and relatable the conflict, the more 
immersive the story. That's so much more important than the world... Get 
some characters, define their fears, put them in a situation they cannot 
change where they're forced to overcome their fears. Starting out with the 
main character, then expanding it to accommodate other individuals that 
need to be introduced in order to tell his/her story.

The world, the setting, ideally is all designed to support the telling of a 
very specific story. An incredible world will not save a mediocre story... 
whereas a good story is timeless, in the sense that setting does not matter 
at all. It's just flavor. (Walking Dead and Toy Story 3 are essentially the 
same story, for instance) The sense of wonder and horror of a zombie 
apocalypse experienced by a sheriff is mirrored in the sense of wonder and 
horror a toy sheriff experiences when he leaves home. Both are stories 
about self-discovery and responsibility by being forced to adapt to an 
unknown world (as are Harry Potter, LOTR, The Matrix, etc.). But it's the 
main character and his/her personal past and goals that define the world 
needed to tell the story. Everything grows from there. Helps keep track of 
which parts of the world need to be defined and which you can leave up to 
the imagination of your audience.
comments.author: Eric Uijlen

comments.text:

comments.text:
I disagree.

 Our world does not seem to have much of a purpose, now does it? Then why 
must fictional worlds obey the rule of having a purpose? I see very little 
entertainment value in knowing exactly what and why is going on, it leaves 
out a very important thing for the reader - imagination.

 Many, many people like to imagine what would go on in a fictional world of 
someone else, imagine new character and come up with their own reasons for 
things to occur for how they occur.

 You see, by giving your crazy imaginary word a detailed, structured and 
written out purpose and explanations, you leave out the creative touch for 
the reader, and only end up with a work of fiction that looks like you are 
trying to explain the real world.
comments.author: Harogrim

top_comment.text:
As a writer and closet fan fiction artist, this is how I create my world(s).
I start by watching a TON of television.
Then continue to act out my own fan fiction as if I was actually in each 
episode.
Eventually I gather up a ton of ideas that I throw into my Theoretical 
"Brain bucket".
One my theoretical brain bucket gets full, I empty it out and try to match 
all the ideas together like a puzzle.
Once I have a cool idea, I build around that and see how I can incorporate 
it into other ideas.
Eventually, my universe starts to grow.
And now, I have a world in my mind larger than most.
YES I WILL ONE DAY BECOME A FAMOUS WRITER! IT MUST COME TO PASS!﻿

captions.text: In J.R.R.'s world,

Gandalf is one of five wizards
sent by the Valar
to guide the inhabitants of Middle Earth

in their struggles
against the dark force of Sauron.
Gandalf's body was mortal,

subject to the physical
rules of Middle Earth,
but his spirit was immortal,
as seen when he died as Gandalf the Grey
and resurrected as Gandalf the White.
According to the Wachowski's script,
an awakened human only has to link up

and hack the neon binary
code of the Matrix

to learn how to fly a helicopter
in a matter of seconds.
Or if you are the One, or one of the Ones,

you don't even need a helicopter,
you just need a cool pair of shades.
Cheshire cats can juggle their own heads.
iPads are rudimentary.

No Quidditch match ends
until the Golden Snitch is caught.

And the answer to the ultimate
question of life, the universe,
and everything
is most certainly 42.

Just like real life,
fictional worlds operate consistently

within a spectrum of physical
and societal rules.
That's what makes these intricate worlds

believable, comprehensible,
and worth exploring.

In real life, the Law of Gravity
holds seven book sets of "Harry Potter"

to millions of bookshelves
around the world.
We know this to be true, but we also know
that ever since J.K. typed the words
wizard, wand, and "Wingardium Leviosa,"
that Law of Gravity has ceased to exist

on the trillions of pages
resting between those bookends.

Authors of science fiction and fantasy
literally build worlds.
They make rules, maps, lineages,
languages, cultures, universes,
alternate universes within universes,

and from those worlds sprout
story, after story, after story.
When it's done well,

readers can understand
fictional worlds and their rules

just as well as the characters
that live in them do
and sometimes, just as well or even better

than the reader understands
the world outside of the book.
But how?
How can human-made squiggles on a page

reflect lights into our eyes
that send signals to our brains

that we logically and emotionally decode
as complex narratives
that move us to fight,
cry, sing, and think,
that are strong enough
not only to hold up a world
that is completely invented by the author,

but also to change
the reader's perspective
on the real world that resumes
only when the final squiggle is reached?

I'm not sure anyone knows
the answer to that question,

yet fantastical, fictional worlds
are created everyday
in our minds, on computers,

even on napkins at the restaurant
down the street.

The truth is your imagination
and a willingness to, figuratively,
live in your own world

are all you need to get
started writing a novel.

I didn't dream up Hogwarts
or the Star Wars' Cantina,

but I have written some science thrillers
for kids and young adults.

Here are some questions
and methods I've used

to help build the worlds
in which those books take place.
I start with a basic place and time.

Whether that's a fantasy world
or a futuristic setting in the real world,

it's important to know where you are
and whether you're working in the past,
present, or future.
I like to create a timeline
showing how the world came to be.

What past events have shaped
the way it is now?
Then I brainstorm answers to questions

that draw out the details
of my fictional world.
What rules are in place here?

This covers everything
from laws of gravity,
or not,
to the rules of society

and the punishments
for individuals who break them.

What kind of government
does this world have?
Who has power, and who doesn't?
What do people believe in here?
And what does this society value most?

Then it's time to think
about day-to-day life.
What's the weather like in this world?

Where do the inhabitants live
and work and go to school?
What do they eat
and how do they play?

How do they treat their young
and their old?

What relationships do they have
with the animals and plants of the world?

And what do those animals
and plants look like?
What kind of technology exists?
Transportation?
Communication?
Access to information?
There's so much to think about!

So, spend some time living in those tasks
and the answers to those questions,

and you're well on your way
to building your own fictional world.

Once you know your world
as well as you hope your reader will,

set your characters free in it
and see what happens.
And ask yourself,

"How does this world you created
shape the individuals who live in it?

And what kind of conflict
is likely to emerge?"

Answer those questions,
and you have your story.
Good luck, future world-builder!

title: How to build a fictional world - Kate Messner
